trans-unit.source: Create a project
trans-unit.target: Create a project

trans-unit.source: Beginner
trans-unit.target: Beginner

trans-unit.source: This page explains how to:
trans-unit.target: This page explains how to:

trans-unit.source: create a new empty project
trans-unit.target: create a new empty project

trans-unit.source: create a project based on a template or sample
trans-unit.target: create a project based on a template or sample

trans-unit.source: Templates are projects that contain just the necessary elements to start working on a game.
trans-unit.target: Templates are projects that contain just the necessary elements to start working on a game.

trans-unit.source: Samples are complete games, which you can learn from or base a new game on.
trans-unit.target: Samples are complete games, which you can learn from or base a new game on.

trans-unit.source: Create an empty project
trans-unit.target: Create an empty project

trans-unit.source: An empty project is project that contains only the bare minimum to make a game: a simple scene with a light, camera, and script to move the camera, plus a preconfigured rendering pipeline. This is good when you want to start your game from scratch without elements you don't need.
trans-unit.target: An empty project is project that contains only the bare minimum to make a game: a simple scene with a light, camera, and script to move the camera, plus a preconfigured rendering pipeline. This is good when you want to start your game from scratch without elements you don't need.

trans-unit.source: To create an empty project:
trans-unit.target: To create an empty project:

trans-unit.source: In the Stride Launcher, click Start to start Game Studio.
trans-unit.target: In the Stride Launcher, click Start to start Game Studio.

trans-unit.source: The New/open project dialog opens.
trans-unit.target: The New/open project dialog opens.

trans-unit.source: New Project dialog
trans-unit.target: New Project dialog

trans-unit.source: You can also open a new project in Game Studio from File > New.
trans-unit.target: You can also open a new project in Game Studio from File > New.

trans-unit.source: Select New Game.
trans-unit.target: Select New Game.

trans-unit.source: In the Name and Location fields, specify a name for the project and the folder to save it in.
trans-unit.target: In the Name and Location fields, specify a name for the project and the folder to save it in.

trans-unit.source: Click Select.
trans-unit.target: Click Select.

trans-unit.source: The Create a new game dialog opens.
trans-unit.target: The Create a new game dialog opens.

trans-unit.source: Create a new game dialog
trans-unit.target: Create a new game dialog

trans-unit.source: In the Namespace field, specify the namespace you want to use. If you don't know what your namespace should be, leave it as default.
trans-unit.target: In the Namespace field, specify the namespace you want to use. If you don't know what your namespace should be, leave it as default.

trans-unit.source: Under Platforms, select the platforms you want your game to support.
trans-unit.target: Under Platforms, select the platforms you want your game to support.

trans-unit.source: !Note > To support iOS and Android, you need to install
trans-unit.target: !Note > To support iOS and Android, you need to install

trans-unit.source: Xamarin (free if you have Visual Studio).
trans-unit.target: Xamarin (free if you have Visual Studio).

trans-unit.source: If your development system is missing prerequisites for any of the platforms you select, Stride displays a warning.
trans-unit.target: If your development system is missing prerequisites for any of the platforms you select, Stride displays a warning.

trans-unit.source: Under Asset Packs, you can select additional assets to include in your project. These include assets such as animations and materials. The asset packs are fun to play with when you're learning how to use Stride, but they're not necessary.
trans-unit.target: Under Asset Packs, you can select additional assets to include in your project. These include assets such as animations and materials. The asset packs are fun to play with when you're learning how to use Stride, but they're not necessary.

trans-unit.source: Under Rendering, select the options you want.
trans-unit.target: Under Rendering, select the options you want.

trans-unit.source: Graphics API: The graphics features you can use in your project depend on the API you select. For advanced graphics features, select the latest version of the graphics APIs.
trans-unit.target: Graphics API: The graphics features you can use in your project depend on the API you select. For advanced graphics features, select the latest version of the graphics APIs.

trans-unit.source: !Warning Some graphics cards don't support the latest APIs. For some mobile devices, only Direct3D 9.3 / OpenGL ES 2.0 and Direct3D 10.0 / OpenGL ES 3.0 are available.
trans-unit.target: !Warning Some graphics cards don't support the latest APIs. For some mobile devices, only Direct3D 9.3 / OpenGL ES 2.0 and Direct3D 10.0 / OpenGL ES 3.0 are available.

trans-unit.source: High or Low Dynamic Range (HDR / LDR): This defines how color is computed in your project. In LDR mode, colors range from 0 to 1. In HDR mode colors can take any float value. HDR provides more advanced and realistic rendering but requires more processing power and profile Direct3D 10.0 / OpenGL ES 3.0 or later.
trans-unit.target: High or Low Dynamic Range (HDR / LDR): This defines how color is computed in your project. In LDR mode, colors range from 0 to 1. In HDR mode colors can take any float value. HDR provides more advanced and realistic rendering but requires more processing power and profile Direct3D 10.0 / OpenGL ES 3.0 or later.

trans-unit.source: Under Orientation, choose the orientation for your project. For PC games, use landscape. Portrait should usually only be used for mobile games.
trans-unit.target: Under Orientation, choose the orientation for your project. For PC games, use landscape. Portrait should usually only be used for mobile games.

trans-unit.source: Click OK.
trans-unit.target: Click OK.

trans-unit.source: Stride creates the project and opens it in Game Studio. For more information, see Game Studio.
trans-unit.target: Stride creates the project and opens it in Game Studio. For more information, see Game Studio.

trans-unit.source: Create a project from a sample or template
trans-unit.target: Create a project from a sample or template

trans-unit.source: Stride includes several sample projects demonstrating each part of the engine (2D, 3D, sprites, fonts, UI, audio, input, etc). It also includes template games to help you make your own game.
trans-unit.target: Stride includes several sample projects demonstrating each part of the engine (2D, 3D, sprites, fonts, UI, audio, input, etc). It also includes template games to help you make your own game.

trans-unit.source: To create a project from a sample or template:
trans-unit.target: To create a project from a sample or template:

trans-unit.source: Open the New Project dialog.
trans-unit.target: Open the New Project dialog.

trans-unit.source: On the left, navigate to New project > Samples.
trans-unit.target: On the left, navigate to New project > Samples.

trans-unit.source: Select the sample you want to create a project from.
trans-unit.target: Select the sample you want to create a project from.

trans-unit.source: New Project window — samples
trans-unit.target: New Project window — samples

trans-unit.source: Click Select.
trans-unit.target: Click Select.

trans-unit.source: The Select Platforms window opens.
trans-unit.target: The Select Platforms window opens.

trans-unit.source: Select Platforms window
trans-unit.target: Select Platforms window

trans-unit.source: Select the platforms you want your game to support and click OK.
trans-unit.target: Select the platforms you want your game to support and click OK.

trans-unit.source: Stride creates the project and opens it in Game Studio.
trans-unit.target: Stride creates the project and opens it in Game Studio.

trans-unit.source: What's next?
trans-unit.target: What's next?
